Award.AwardTitle: Dissertations Symposium in Chemical Oceanography XXIV and XXV
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Hawaii's Outreach College will continue management of the 24th and 25th Dissertations Symposium in Chemical Oceanography (DISCO), a conference originally begun in 1978. These symposia provide recently graduated or soon to graduate, PhD level chemical oceanographers with an opportunity to present their dissertation research in front of their peers, and to forge professional relationships that will facilitate their future research and academic careers. The meeting will also offer the opportunity to interact with their peers in physical oceanography given the Physical Oceanography Dissertation Symposium will run concurrently with DISCO, as well as engage in discussions with agency personnel to better understand funding mechanisms and strategies. DISCO XXIV and DISCO XXV will be held in Honolulu, Hawaii from October 5-9, 2014 and October 2-6, 2016, respectively. Applicants eligible for participation in a given DISCO meeting are those individuals who have received their doctoral degrees in ocean chemistry within one year preceding that symposium or who are certified by the degree-granting institution as graduating within one year after that symposium. An applicant pool will be developed for the meetings from a broad international announcement to chemical oceanographers at academic institutions in the US and other countries, as well as an announcement in EOS magazine. From this pool, agency personnel will select invitees. This symposium is jointly sponsored by the National Science Foundation and the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration.

Broader Impacts: As in previous years, these Symposia will aid in furthering the professional development of early career chemical oceanographers, both U.S. and international, who will play a critical role in improving our understanding of ocean and earth science processes. Because the worldwide marine chemistry research community is relatively small and spread out, these Symposia offer an important opportunity for early-career U.S. and non-U.S scientists to meet and develop life-long associations. The meeting location in the Hawaiian Islands provides an important opportunity for the majority of participants to arrange time to witness marine basaltic volcanism first-hand, visit the acclaimed Hawaiian Ocean Time-Series locale, and see the iconic site of atmospheric carbon dioxide monitoring on Mauna Loa.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided funds to organize and conduct two conferences for newly graduated, or soon to graduate, PhD recipients in the field of Chemical Oceanography.  The new scientists selected to participate in this conference through a competitive process (25 attendees from over 60 qualified applicants) are conducting research at the forefront of our knowledge of the oceans and are expected to represent the next generation of chemical oceanographers.  This conference is designed to enhance cohort group formation amongst these young scientists, to foster future collaborative interactions, which will forward progress in the field.  These conferences were held in October of 2014 and 2016. Grant funds were used to develop a conference website (www.soest.hawaii.edu/DISCO), fund participant travel and hotel costs, and pay for meeting logistics such as conference rooms, audio-visual support, and meeting-related printed materials.  The purpose of the meeting website is to provide information about the meeting, application materials, and answer any frequently-asked-questions regarding the meeting. For the 2014 and 2016 symposia, advertising posters were designed and delivered to NSF to distribute at the AGU Fall 2013/2015 and Spring Ocean Sciences 2014/2016 meetings, as well as any other locales deemed appropriate. We also contacted various organizations and community-wide list serves within the oceanographic community and asked them to send out announcements of the symposium to their address list. Applications were solicited from qualified individuals via the means described above, with application forms available on the meeting website. Completed applications were received via email to the conference organizers and compiled for transmission to NSF program managers.  We received 77 applications for the 2014 symposium and 62 applications for the 2016 symposium.  Once participants were selected, we invited those people via email to the meeting.  Once positive confirmation of the intent to attend the conference was received for all available seats, unsuccessful applicants were notified that they had not been selected.  NSF program managers also chose a single senior guest speaker for each meeting (from Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute and Columbia University), who we then helped with logistical support to attend the meetings. Successful applicants were contacted with a request to provide travel information for booking air tickets and hotel rooms. To facilitate this process, a detailed Google-form travel form was developed, streamlining communications between the participant, travel agent, and logistics coordinator. We then prepared the meeting agenda, abstract booklet and collected roster information from all participants.  An e-version and a printed version of this booklet was given to all participants.  We also compiled the following materials for participants: name badges, local restaurant information, local maps, talk (speaker) evaluation forms and meeting evaluation forms.  The meeting evaluation forms were collected at the meeting's end and feedback compiled into a summary worksheet sent to NSF program managers. This grant was also used to partially fund the COME ABOARD (Chemical Oceanography Meeting: A Bottom-Up Approach to Research Directions) meeting in 2016 (starting the day following the DISCO 2016 meeting), bringing together more senior chemical oceanographers to discuss the future of the field and make recommendations for priorities of study. It resulted in a peer-reviewed manuscript, Perspectives on Chemical Oceanography in the 21st century: Participants of the COME ABOARD Meeting examine aspects of the field in the context of 40 years of DISCO (Marine Chemistry, 196 (2017) 181-190). The article was published as open access, paid for from this grant.
